nodes.question: System shows no signs of life. First step: Check if the wall outlet is working by plugging in another device.

knowledge.text: Plug in a lamp, phone charger, or anything else to the same outlet. If it powers, your outlet is fine. If not, move to another outlet or reset the breaker.

nodes.result: The outlet has no power. Restore wall power or switch to a known-good outlet before proceeding.

knowledge.text: Reset the breaker, turn on the switch if it’s a switched outlet, or move your PC to a confirmed working outlet.

nodes.question: Verify the PSU rear switch is ON. Do fans or LEDs react?

knowledge.text: On the back of your PSU is a small rocker switch. Make sure it’s in the 'I' position, not 'O'. If your PSU has a 115V/230V selector, ensure it matches your region.

nodes.question: Perform the PSU paperclip test or try a known-good PSU. Does the PSU turn on by itself?

knowledge.text: Unplug PSU from the PC. On the 24-pin connector, short the green wire to any black wire with a bent paperclip. If the PSU fan spins, it’s alive. Or swap in a spare PSU.

nodes.result: The PSU failed testing. Replace the power supply.

knowledge.text: If the PSU does not start with the paperclip test or a tester, it’s faulty. Replace with a new unit of equal or better wattage.

nodes.question: Are 24-pin ATX and CPU 8-pin EPS connectors fully seated?

knowledge.text: Check that the big 24-pin cable is fully inserted in the motherboard. Also check the 8-pin (sometimes 4+4) near the CPU. Push until they click. Only use the PSU’s own modular cables — never mix brands.

nodes.question: Check case power button wiring. Try shorting PWR_SW pins directly with a screwdriver. Did the system power on?

knowledge.text: Follow your motherboard manual to confirm case button wiring is correct. To bypass, tap the two PWR_SW pins with a screwdriver tip. If it powers on, the button or wiring is bad.

nodes.result: If still nothing after all prior steps, suspect motherboard or CPU.

knowledge.text: If you’ve verified outlet, PSU, and power connections, but still no life, the motherboard or CPU is the most likely failure.

nodes.question: System powers on then shuts off within a few seconds. Next step: Check standoffs / shorts under the motherboard.

knowledge.text: Ensure the motherboard is screwed into standoffs, not directly touching the case. Shorts against the case can cause instant shutoff.

nodes.question: Disconnect the RESET SW header (leave only PWR_SW connected). Does it still shut off?

knowledge.text: A stuck or miswired RESET switch causes instant power cycling. Pull the RESET SW plug off the front-panel header to rule it out.

nodes.question: Breadboard the system (CPU + 1 RAM stick + GPU/onboard). Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Remove the motherboard from the case. Place it on cardboard or wood. Install only CPU, 1 stick of RAM, and GPU (if needed). Connect PSU and power pins, then try to boot.

nodes.question: Does the system stay on longer if you remove RAM or GPU?

knowledge.text: Remove components like RAM or GPU and retry. If the system stays on longer, one of them may be faulty.

nodes.question: Fans and LEDs stay on, but no display. Any debug indicators?
Before we open the case: is the monitor/cable/input correct and plugged into the right port?

knowledge.text: 1) Power the monitor on and set the correct input (HDMI/DP). 2) Try a second cable/port and, if possible, a second display. 3) If a graphics card is installed, plug the cable into the GPU outputs — not the motherboard. 4) Avoid adapters/risers for this test; some DP/HDMI adapters and riser cables are flaky.

nodes.question: Unplug ALL USB/peripherals (rear and front). Leave only power, monitor, and keyboard. Any change?

knowledge.text: Faulty USB devices, dongles, or a shorted front-panel USB header can block POST. Unplug everything: USB hubs, Wi-Fi dongles, external drives, card readers, printers, etc.

nodes.question: What kind of beeps?

knowledge.text: Motherboard beep codes vary. Count the beeps. Long/short patterns indicate which part failed.

nodes.result: Consult your motherboard manual’s beep code table.

knowledge.text: Every BIOS vendor has unique beep meanings. Check your motherboard manual or website.

nodes.question: Which debug LED stays lit?

knowledge.text: Most modern boards have small LEDs labeled CPU, DRAM, VGA, BOOT. The lit one shows the failing stage.

nodes.question: Reseat all RAM sticks. Does the system POST?

knowledge.text: Remove all RAM sticks. Reinsert them firmly until the latches click. Try again.

nodes.result: Consult motherboard manual for debug code meanings.

knowledge.text: If your board shows a hex code like 00 or 55, check the manual’s debug code section.

nodes.question: System powers on but no display. First step: reseat your RAM sticks. Did it POST?

knowledge.text: Remove all RAM sticks. Reinsert them firmly until the latches click. Try again.

nodes.question: Try booting with a single RAM stick in slot A2. Did it POST?

knowledge.text: Remove all but one stick of RAM. Place it in slot A2 (second slot from CPU on most boards). Boot again.

nodes.question: Test each RAM stick in every slot. Any POST?

knowledge.text: Try each stick one at a time in each slot. This helps find a bad stick or bad slot.

nodes.question: Clear CMOS (reset BIOS settings). Does the system POST afterward?

knowledge.text: Turn off PSU. Press the case power button to discharge. Remove the round CMOS battery for 1–2 minutes, or move the jumper, or press the CLR_CMOS button (see manual). Replace and power on.

nodes.question: After clearing CMOS, did you let it sit powered on for 3–5 minutes for memory training? It may reboot several times.

knowledge.text: AM4/AM5 and DDR5 boards often take a few minutes to train RAM after a CMOS clear. Don’t power off during this period.

nodes.question: Check CPU power cables (EPS 4/8-pin near the CPU). Are they fully seated?

knowledge.text: Ensure the CPU’s 8-pin (sometimes 4+4) connector is firmly locked into the socket near the CPU. Without this, CPU won’t run. EPS and PCIe 8-pins look similar — don’t mix them.

nodes.question: Could your CPU require a newer BIOS for this motherboard? Does your board support BIOS Flashback?

knowledge.text: Newer CPUs on older boards may need a BIOS update before video output works. If your board has BIOS Flashback, you can update without a CPU/GPU. Check the manual for the exact port/file name.

nodes.question: Reseat CPU and check socket pins. Does the system POST afterward?

knowledge.text: Remove CPU cooler. Unlock socket. Carefully lift CPU, inspect pins (or pads for AMD). Reinsert aligned properly. Reapply paste and cooler.

nodes.question: Check CPU cooler mounting pressure. Too tight or too loose can prevent boot. Adjust and retry. Did it POST?

knowledge.text: A cooler that’s overtightened can warp the motherboard, while a loose cooler can stop CPU from running. Adjust screws evenly.

nodes.question: Verify GPU PCIe power cables are connected. Any change?

knowledge.text: Check that the 6-pin, 8-pin, or 12-pin GPU power connectors are fully inserted. Some GPUs need more than one cable.

nodes.question: Reseat GPU in the primary PCIe slot. Does the system POST?

knowledge.text: Remove GPU by pressing down the PCIe latch at the end of the slot. Reinsert until it clicks. Reconnect power cables.

nodes.question: Test onboard graphics (plug monitor into motherboard). Do you get a display?

knowledge.text: If your CPU has integrated graphics, connect your monitor directly to the motherboard’s HDMI/DP port. Remove GPU first if unsure.

nodes.question: Disconnect all drives to isolate the boot device. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Unplug all SATA and NVMe drives except one known-good boot drive. This rules out dead drives blocking POST.

nodes.result: System POSTs successfully (you can see BIOS or a display). Issue resolved.
All basic troubleshooting exhausted. Suspect faulty motherboard, CPU, or GPU. Swap with known-good parts for confirmation.

knowledge.text: At this point, replace/test motherboard, CPU, and GPU one at a time with known-good spares.
